Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They encounter choices where Christian ethics become more relevant
Story:
This weekend, my husband and I are expecting his relatives to visit, and the house is in chaos. As a wife, I know it’s my responsibility to help make everything perfect—cleaning, cooking, making sure every detail is just right. My husband expects me to coordinate the chores, and I feel the pressure to meet his family’s standards. But as I’m scrubbing the kitchen, I overhear him on the phone, making up a story about why the house might not be spotless, blaming our busy schedules and even exaggerating my workload. He wants me to go along with it, to nod and smile if anyone asks. 

But my Christian values tug at me. Honesty is important, and I know I shouldn’t support a lie, even a small one meant to save face. I feel torn—should I support my husband and keep the peace, or should I gently correct the story, risking embarrassment and tension? My heart pounds as I set down the sponge, caught between my roles as a supportive wife and a faithful Christian, unsure which expectation I can bear to disappoint.
